Tay Thoughts I think Wikipedia

@Tay Thoughts
 I can't speak for others, but leftism in the sense I use generally refers to anti-capitalist or anti-state positions rooted in a desire to reach a more egalitarian social state, which is often often drawn from leftist philosophy. This would be things like anarchism, communism, socialism, etc etc. Liberals, by and large, are comfortable with the exploitive nature of capitalism, and even if they sometimes argue in favor of making things better for marginalized groups within this system (depending on which liberals), they fail to recognize the systemic harm to well being that capitalism creates by necessity to preserve the current overall heirarchal inequality. They prefer a negative peace and are comfortable with the status quo, but sometimes will speak out for comparatively small changes that wouldn't uproot the status quo at large, usually once corporate interests align towards monetizing those changes. This can be summed up in those memes where every word is separated by clapping hand emotes. Compare and contrast to conservatives, who also support corporate interests over the individuals, but are also more traditionally entrenched anti-egalitarian values. They fight against literally any attempt to move forward progress wise.

I think it helps to remember that the left-right spectrum is generally relative to the status quo, too. Being left of absolute monarchists isn't exactly all that different from being a conservative (actual conservatives btw not fascists playing pretend so they can recruit) today because conservatives can and are, at least officially, left of absolute monarchists and feudalism, since the traditions they fight for are the ones rooted in modern thought that has by and large rejected absolute monarchism and feudalism in favor of capitalism, which was rooted in egalitarian values when it started cropping up. Obviously, things change, capitalism is now the dominant means of societal organization. As such, left and right as relevant to the status quo have also changed.

Obviously though, it's kinda hard to pin down an objective measure of what constitutes left vs right that accounts for every single variation of political thought, hence why there's a million different contradicting political charts and graphs. I do acknowledge that. I just think that leftism as it is now refers primarily to anti-capitalist, anti-state, egalitarian positions. Liberalism just ain't it. Unless you're a conservative, of course, because leftism is an easy boogeyman to pin all societal problems on when one can strawman it hard enough.
Tay Thoughts liberal values (liberty, egalitarianism, and fraternity) are lefty, but liberalism as a system and ideology is right wing

@Tay Thoughts 
If we were discussing purely the origin rather than how it's used today, I'd agree with you. We're not, though. We're talking about the word as it's used now, in the circles i mentioned earlier. It seems odd to use the context of where the word started off without considering how the meaning has changed to reflext the values of today. If we ignore all modern context, the fuckload of leftist philosophy that's come out and carved a niche for itself, and the way that has shaped politics, we would have to assert that modern conservatives are leftists, because, as i said, they are left of absolute monarchists.
No one does this. Conservatives don't call themselves leftists, they blame the left for every problem that exists literally ever to make their obsession with preserving all heirarchal and moral values that they advocate for look good. To ignore this fact that exists today because liberalism is left of absolute monarchists just doesn't make sense to me at all.

Also, slightly different note, can you like, not misinterpret what I'm saying? You went on this gigantic tangent to imply that I'm asserting that words don't have objective definitions. I'm not saying they don't. I'm saying that context also matters. If you go into the leftist groups i mentioned earlier, liberals are gonna seen as right wing. Left of conservatives in terms of the pursuit of a more egalitarian society  but not left of the center (capitalism). The n word is a perfect example of context mattering. Without context, it just means "a black person". With context it becomes either a perjorative due to the systems that reinforce heirarchies which are reaponsible for said hard, or a term of endearment. It fundamentally becomes different in meaning even though the definition stays the same. To answer your hypothetical, i believe that if the systemic constructs that harm people based on race stop being a supported thing, then the n word will no longer cause the harm it did, because the thing that gave it its power would no longer exist except as a historical occurence, which would, incidentally, have to include things like privilege. Kinda hard for there to be privileged whites in a society where constructs and environmental factors no longer reinforce the harmful elements of a word. When this comes to pass, it would probably live on as a term of endearment, because that's a thing that exists now. Or maybe it wouldn't. It really doesn't matter one way or the other. What matters is that the harmful meaning wouldn't have any weight, and would likely cease being relevant.

Please, stop pretending that only definition matters when we interpret language. It's dishonest as fuck to misinterpret what someone is arguing in order to defeat that argument instead of the original, and reeks of predatory intent. That's not something I'm okay with enabling.
Cora supports centricide? Oh shit, she really IS Jreg.

@Tay Thoughts Wait, what are you even arguing? You and the person you were responding to seem to be talking past each other. Your op was arguing that liberalism is on the left of the political spectrum, which may be true, but doesn't negate the fact that liberalism as an ideological descriptor is different from leftism as an ideological descriptor. You didn't really respond to the comment expanding on the differences -- do you not think drawing a distinction between capitalist and anti-capitalist matters?


"So at what point do you, and all you who think this way, believe we should stop using words the way they are generally used?" 


I would agree that most people use leftism incorrectly, but I think you're failing to take into account the fact that leftism itself is pretty fringe. Your examples of "troll" and the N word are not applicable because although they have history, at the end of the day they're simply pejorative descriptors rather than terms that indicate schools of academic and intellectual thought and therefore have utilitarian value. Your argument only works if you're of the mind that there is no utility to discussing any concept outside of that which is accepted by the mainstream, because that's the point of the leftist/liberal distinction. It definitely does makes sense for you to take as a liberal though, if you want to push leftism outside the realm of consideration and seem more radical than you are.


So a counter question to you would be: At what point do anti-capitalists, as a fringe ideology, stop drawing distinctions between ourselves and capitalist liberals simply because (depending of the context) liberals are sometimes left of center, and because the smooth-brains on Fox News don't know the difference anyway?
